Line 4: Line 4:
Because most of the kernel and supporting packages are some combination of [[free software]] and [[open-source software|open source]], Linux distributions have taken a wide variety of forms â from fully featured desktop and server operating systems to minimal environments (typically for use in [[embedded system]]s, or for [[booting]] from a floppy disk). Aside from certain custom software (such as installers and configuration tools) a "distro" simply refers to a particular assortment of applications married with a particularly compiled kernel, such that its "out-of-the-box" capabilities meets most of the needs of its particular end-user base.
Because most of the kernel and supporting packages are some combination of [[free software]] and [[open-source software|open source]], Linux distributions have taken a wide variety of forms â from fully featured desktop and server operating systems to minimal environments (typically for use in [[embedded system]]s, or for [[booting]] from a floppy disk). Aside from certain custom software (such as installers and configuration tools) a "distro" simply refers to a particular assortment of applications married with a particularly compiled kernel, such that its "out-of-the-box" capabilities meets most of the needs of its particular end-user base.
â
One can distinguish between commercially backed distributions, such as [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] ([[Red Hat]]), [[SUSE Linux]] ([[Novell]]), [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]] ([[Canonical Ltd.]]), and [[Mandriva Linux]] and community distributions such as [[Debian]] and [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]]. The procedures for assembling and testing a distribution prior to release tend to become more elaborate the larger the user base.
+
One can distinguish between commercially backed distributions, such as [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] ([[Red Hat]]), [[SUSE Linux]] ([[Novell]]), [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] ([[Canonical Ltd.]]), and [[Mandriva Linux]] and community distributions such as [[Debian]] and [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]]. The procedures for assembling and testing a distribution prior to release tend to become more elaborate the larger the user base.
Line 69: Line 69:
The read-only nature of CDs and DVDs means that user data cannot be stored with the operating system, but must be written to some other device (such as a USB flash drive or an installed hard drive) if any is to be kept. Temporary operating system data is usually kept solely in [[random access memory|RAM]].
The read-only nature of CDs and DVDs means that user data cannot be stored with the operating system, but must be written to some other device (such as a USB flash drive or an installed hard drive) if any is to be kept. Temporary operating system data is usually kept solely in [[random access memory|RAM]].
â
The portablility is advantageous for applications such as demonstrations, borrowing someone else's computer, rescue operations, and as installation media for a standard distribution. Many popular distributions come in both "Live" and conventional forms (the conventional form being a network or removable media image which is intended to be used for installation only). This includes [[SUSE]], [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], [[Mepis]], and [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]]. Some distributions, such as [[Knoppix]] and [[Dyne:bolic]], are designed primarily for LiveCD or LiveDVD use.
+
The portablility is advantageous for applications such as demonstrations, borrowing someone else's computer, rescue operations, and as installation media for a standard distribution. Many popular distributions come in both "Live" and conventional forms (the conventional form being a network or removable media image which is intended to be used for installation only). This includes [[SUSE]], [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], [[Mepis]], and [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]]. Some distributions, such as [[Knoppix]] and [[Dyne:bolic]], are designed primarily for LiveCD or LiveDVD use.

Line 87: Line 87:
* [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]], which is a derivative of [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] maintained and commercially supported by [[Red Hat]]
* [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]], which is a derivative of [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] maintained and commercially supported by [[Red Hat]]
* [[Slackware]], one of the first Linux distributions, founded in 1993, and since then actively maintained by [[Patrick J. Volkerding]]
* [[Slackware]], one of the first Linux distributions, founded in 1993, and since then actively maintained by [[Patrick J. Volkerding]]
â
* [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], a newly popular desktop distribution maintained by [[Canonical Ltd|Canonical]] that is derived from Debian.
+
* [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], a newly popular desktop distribution maintained by [[Canonical Ltd|Canonical]] that is derived from Debian.
[[DistroWatch]] maintains a popularity ranking of distribution information on its web site, but this is not considered to be a reliable measure of distribution popularity.
[[DistroWatch]] maintains a popularity ranking of distribution information on its web site, but this is not considered to be a reliable measure of distribution popularity.
Line 93: Line 93:
===Niche distributions===
===Niche distributions===
â
Jesux<ref>[http://www.geocities.com/ResearchTriangle/Node/4081/ Jesux<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> was a fake Christianity-inspired distribution that used the [[Bourne Again Shell]] by default, provided hex modes in order to avoid typing "666", and allowed the user to optionally restrict logins on the [[Sabbath in Christianity|Sabbath]].<ref>[http://news.zdnet.co.uk/software/0,1000000121,2074077,00.htm Jesux hoax uncovered - ZDNet UK<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Another, the [[Buddhist]] Yellow Hat GNU/Linux, was an [[April Fools' Day]] hoax perpetrated by [[Richard M. Stallman]].<ref>http://www.stallman.org/articles/yellow-hat.html</ref> More recently, however, two forks of the [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]] distribution have made serious attempts at marketing Linux to Christian clergy and organizations: Ichthux, and [[Ubuntu Christian Edition]] both bundle Bible-oriented applications and theological dictionaries in their main distributions.
+
Jesux<ref>[http://www.geocities.com/ResearchTriangle/Node/4081/ Jesux<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> was a fake Christianity-inspired distribution that used the [[Bourne Again Shell]] by default, provided hex modes in order to avoid typing "666", and allowed the user to optionally restrict logins on the [[Sabbath in Christianity|Sabbath]].<ref>[http://news.zdnet.co.uk/software/0,1000000121,2074077,00.htm Jesux hoax uncovered - ZDNet UK<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Another, the [[Buddhist]] Yellow Hat GNU/Linux, was an [[April Fools' Day]] hoax perpetrated by [[Richard M. Stallman]].<ref>http://www.stallman.org/articles/yellow-hat.html</ref> More recently, however, two forks of the [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] distribution have made serious attempts at marketing Linux to Christian clergy and organizations: Ichthux, and [[Ubuntu Christian Edition]] both bundle Bible-oriented applications and theological dictionaries in their main distributions.
Other distributions are targeted at other specific niches such as the tiny embedded router distribution [[OpenWrt]], the Ubuntu project to create [[Edubuntu]] for educational users, and [[KnoppMyth]] which wraps [[Knoppix]] around [[MythTV]] to ease building Linux-powered [[DVR]]s.
Other distributions are targeted at other specific niches such as the tiny embedded router distribution [[OpenWrt]], the Ubuntu project to create [[Edubuntu]] for educational users, and [[KnoppMyth]] which wraps [[Knoppix]] around [[MythTV]] to ease building Linux-powered [[DVR]]s.
Line 137: Line 137:
=== Installation through an existing platform ===
=== Installation through an existing platform ===
â
Most recently, a [https://wiki.ubuntu.com/install.exe/Prototype Windows installer] for [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu Linux]] was developed. This allows for one to download and install a Linux distribution without the need for hard drive partitioning or the need for an installation CD, thus allowing for the option to easily dual boot between either operating system on the same hard drive without losing data. This was followed by the release of a [http://goodbye-microsoft.com/ Windows installer] for [[Debian]]. The Windows installer for Debian (known internally as ''win32-loader'') is in the process of being integrated in official Debian CDs/DVDs.{{Fact|date=September 2007}}.
+
Most recently, a [https://wiki.ubuntu.com/install.exe/Prototype Windows installer] for [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] was developed. This allows for one to download and install a Linux distribution without the need for hard drive partitioning or the need for an installation CD, thus allowing for the option to easily dual boot between either operating system on the same hard drive without losing data. This was followed by the release of a [http://goodbye-microsoft.com/ Windows installer] for [[Debian]]. The Windows installer for Debian (known internally as ''win32-loader'') is in the process of being integrated in official Debian CDs/DVDs.{{Fact|date=September 2007}}.
